Author: xDD90x
Comment: The gameplay looks fun and I have faith in Rocksteady to deliver a good game with a good story, but I just have no interest in the Suicide Squad. It‚Äôs the same reason I didn‚Äôt play Gotham Knights. Those characters just don‚Äôt have the same appeal as Spider-Man, Batman, and Superman. I would bet the idea for this game immerged from an early attempt to conceptualize a Superman game. Faced with all the challenges developing a game where you play as a near-invincible character would entail, someone likely hatched the idea that Superman would make for a better boss character than a player character, and so the concept of SSKTJ was born. It‚Äôs shocking that it‚Äôs been 17 years since a Superman game was released. I still believe a good Superman game could be achieved with enough ingenuity and ambition.

Author: Mikutow
Comment: Naughty Dog, what are you doing this gen??  I know I have posted negative comments before, and I don‚Äôt mean to be negative and rude, but I really am just disappointed and sad that one of my favorite studios has turned into a shell of themselves.  No new game announcements, no actual new IP, and a cancelled project, that not only looked promising and fun, but it was promised as a part of TLOU2.  Instead, all you have done is port your games from PS4 to PS5 with little reason to re-buy them.  What are you doing?  How can the best PS Studio fall so hard.  You don‚Äôt have to release ‚Äúperfect games‚Äù.  You CAN release fun games at a higher rate.  Look at Fromsoft.  They are proof the games industry doesn‚Äôt need 10 year development cycles to make great games at a fast pace.  I just feel let down by Naughty Dog, and especially Playstation Studios this gen.  Where are the games!  Where are the new IP?

Author: ModTheMod14
Comment: The discussion has become much bigger than this game or Rocksteady for us gamers. It is about WB (and other companies in the industry) openly and shamelessly trying to force service game after service game down our throat, where not FUN or an AWESOME GAMING EXPERIENCE are leading game-development and decision-making but MONETIZATION, PLAYER RETENTION, FEAR OF ‚ÄúOVERDELIVERY‚Äù and other corporate buzzwords and behavioral psychology tricks, and it plainly and wholeheartedly just sucks!The ONLY language those corporates understand is MONEY, therefore a service-game like Suicide Squad, which asks a full premium price AND THEN more and more and more money through battle passes, skins and whatnot, should just not be supported by gamers. Look at Marvels Spider-Man 2, a game by Insomniac, a passionate single player oriented studio focused on delivering awesome experiences: they made a banger game, GOTY contender, where you also could unlock like 99% (without Deluxe Edition content) of cosmetics THROUGH GAMEPLAY, NOT GAMEPAY, and thats how it should be and should be honoured with our money: a premium price for a premium product! If YOU support Suicide Squad and ohter games like this, make no mistake: you are hurting yourself as a gamer, because the industry as a whole will move into a direction, where pretty much every game coming out will be an ALWAYS-ONLINE LOOTER SHOOTER FORTNITE CLONE with dumbed down gameplay and cut content, because they are selling it to you later. Please dont let them get away with this, Im begging you on behalf of gaming as the thought.provoking, creative, multifacetted and interactive medium we all love and enjoy (and btw: are also more than willing to pay for, just give us premium single player games, for gods sake, and bath in money!).

Author: weatherkid94
Comment: No disc drive attachment should ever require an internet connection to function. Period. I‚Äôm not trying to be anti-internet or anything like that, but I‚Äôm really disappointed that Sony is pulling an unnecessary stunt like this. Also, I am really hoping someone can confirm if the new PS5 slim would need to pair up the disc drive over the internet again after a factory reset and if it does, this requirement needs to be nerfed right now. I understand it‚Äôs not 2013 anymore, but gamers should have a right to play their systems offline if they want too, even if they do have internet.

Author: fourfour44
Comment: Every console made over the last 10+ years has required the optical drive to be paired with the logic board. This is no different, they‚Äôre just offering the optical drive as a post purchase add-on, meaning it‚Äôll still need to get paired with the logic board of the system it‚Äôs attached to. If you have any ideas for another way to accomplish this then feel free to share them, but a simple and quick online registration like they‚Äôre doing seems pretty reasonable to me and it‚Äôs very strange to see so many people making such a fuss over this complete non-issue. Aside from the original Wii, every console with an optical drive since the 360 has had it paired with the logic board, it‚Äôs something that needs to be addressed if you‚Äôre looking at getting a repair done. What Sony is doing here is no different, but since it can‚Äôt be done at the factory at time of manufacture it‚Äôs done when you boot it up and register the console.

Author: weatherkid94
Comment: Didn‚Äôt think anyone would reply to this comment. Yeah, I am aware that these disc drives are paired with a piece of hardware for years now, prohibiting repair.The point I‚Äôm trying to make here is that the disc drives here on the new systems should not require an online activation and it defeats the purpose of supporting physical games entirely. I‚Äôm sure some people are going to say that the physical games are buggy, incomplete, or intentionally unplayable, but there are still a few new releases that do ship out in a solid state.If anyone wants to ignore this issue and defend Sony or some random law making the appalling decisions, that‚Äôs fine. At this point, I am pretty much done with PlayStation and I am already considering moving to a PC since the world is moving towards a digital only future.Also, it has been confirmed today that the disc drive unregisters with the system during the factory reset process. The original large PS5 model never had this problem and this one should never have it in the first place. If GT7‚Äôs 48 hour server outage wasn‚Äôt enough to convince the developers to remove the always online requirement for the single player career mode and other local play features, I don‚Äôt think Sony would care enough to remove the online activation for the PS5 slim‚Äôs disc drive since it doesn‚Äôt get enough backlash. I really wanted to like this redesigned system with its modular disc drive, but I guess it was just too good to be true.

Author: fourfour44
Comment: Nowhere in your reply did you suggest an alternative to the pairing process and instead talk about general purpose personal computers as if the endless hassles of dealing with that, especially Windows, are some sort of competition or replacement for a dedicated gaming console. But no, it‚Äôs Sony that‚Äôs the problem with a perfectly reasonable requirement for something that nobody who doesn‚Äôt have terminal online brain will even take notice of at all because for every normal person out there it‚Äôll be totally seamless and not noticeable at all.

Author: weatherkid94
Comment: I apologize for not answering the question on accomplishing a solution to the disc pairing method. Just design the hardware without any complex software barriers. All you have to do is attach the hardware, plug and play the system, simple as that. It shouldn‚Äôt be that difficult. I don‚Äôt really write comments on blogs that much, so I felt like I need to make a statement to call out on Sony for doing this, although it‚Äôs not going to make any difference. I‚Äôm not trying to strike a nerve on some people reading the comments to believe I‚Äôm attacking Sony on something that I personally felt like what they are doing is wrong. We can agree to disagree on how hardware pairing should function. I think it‚Äôs absurd and the PS5 slim should‚Äôve just went digital only and not have physical disc support at all. A lot of people have an internet connection and don‚Äôt find this requirement to be a big deal I get it. But I‚Äôm just raising the alarm for those who still care about long term access to games they hold near and dear to them and may want to revisit those games decades from now. Once those servers go off in the future, those disc drives are going to be useless paperweight. Again, it‚Äôs fine if gamers want to set their systems up online and play them while connected, but they should have the right to do it offline as well. I will agree on one thing though, the internet is an important part of our lives, but it shouldn‚Äôt be a prerequisite requirement for everything, including the ability to play most video games.

Author: Chaosbros
Comment: It has to be paired in some way otherwise you‚Äôd be able to plug in a third party device that could read pirated discs. Using an online check is a really quick and easy solution. Yes it‚Äôs not ideal but if you purchased a digital only PS5 you obviously have internet access and when you add the disc drive it‚Äôll be a none issue.

Author: weatherkid94
Comment: While I do respect the efforts of game system manufacturers increasing the security to fight back against piracy, I‚Äôm not really sure if having the authentication system for activating the disc drive should be tied to an online server. Maybe what Sony should‚Äôve done instead is have that activation system built in the system‚Äôs software instead to verify if the disc drive is legit or not. Anything that‚Äôs not legit could block the system off from PlayStation Network services as well. They could also use a proprietary connection for the hardware although I am not sure what type of connection the disc drive uses. Look, I love PlayStation, and I‚Äôve been playing with their hardware for over 20 years now. I would never support or promote piracy in anyway and the game developers that pour their hearts and souls into the games they make deserve credit and respect for what they do. I‚Äôm really disappointed with the way Sony designed the PS5 slim by making the disc drive inactive without requiring activation that‚Äôs being held captive on a server. This could all change with a software update later on, but it may never happen. I know physical media is already looking to be phased out soon, and that‚Äôs why I wanted to call out on Sony to make changes on how a detachable disc drive should be set up. I know the online server method isn‚Äôt a bad idea right now, but with all due respect, it would be really difficult going back to play physical copies of some of the PS5 games that are completed on disc in the next few decades once Sony decides to shut the servers down. The disc drive would have to be activated again if the system goes through a factory reset, a restore process, and other system related maintenance. Sony really needs to figure out how to fix this problem with the slim model because I highly doubt future game systems are going to keep supporting physical media moving forward. The original large model never had this problem and the new systems that support disc drives shouldn‚Äôt ether.

Author: lediv
Comment: Because Aloy is not Shepard or Geralt. Aloy is not shaped by us outside of a few small moments and even then all responses are within character for her. For example, Geralt would never kill a friend of his out of spite, would never leave his friends to die and would never betray Ciri‚Äôs trust. But the player might want to because we control Geralt in this story. Aloy hasn‚Äôt shown any interest in anyone besides Seyka because she‚Äôs never been interested in her other friends. Erend, Varl, Petra, Vanasha, Avad, Teb, Alva and Kotallo are people she sees only as friends. With Seyka she like is attracted to her because she reminds Aloy of Rost and because the events of Forbidden West has resulted in her lowering her defenses so she is now more open to the idea of romantic love. Again, Aloy is not the player character and we can only make minor choices outside of a few events. With characters like Shepard and Hawke, they are shaped by the player and as such their sexuality is left up the player. Aloy is Aloy, and her sexuality is her own.

Author: Moftwell
Comment: Can‚Äôt let this pass without noting lediv doesn‚Äôt mention Talanah in their ‚Äònever been interested‚Äô list. Given what Michel Lef√®vre says here about Guerrilla making deliberate choices in facial animation during cutscenes, I (again and on behalf of many) submit ‚ÄúYou‚Ä¶ love him, don‚Äôt you?‚Äù outside of Thornmarsh to be entered into evidence for this case. There‚Äôs a lot more going on below the surface with Horizon‚Äôs characters! I do think the story with Seyka was important to tell ‚Äì both for Aloy‚Äôs development and for the beauty of the story as it stands alone ‚Äì but I have to say I agree that opening the options up further to players in a third game would be a smart evolution for the series. Guerrilla made adjustments in traversal (flying, climbing mechanics) and melee combat between HZD and HFW ‚Äì in no small part due to audience expectations based on industry trends ‚Äì and the idea of even limited agency over romance remains extremely popular (not just historically in the Witcher series or Mass Effect, but also recently with Baldur‚Äôs Gate). So I think it‚Äôs a reasonable bit of feedback for the wish list. Part of the proof of a studio writing great, memorable characters is people becoming heavily invested in their outcomes. Guerrilla have certainly achieved this. It‚Äôd be nice if they feel they can afford to put a bit more of that into players‚Äô hands when they come to wrap Aloy‚Äôs story up.

It‚Äôs a UX design disaster. I just focus on the subtitles but what‚Äôs GREAT /s is when the scene changes, the screen goes black to change to the next set of information, and it blacks out the subtitles as well. I really hope that gets fixed. Yes I know you can skip the briefings, but I like FEELING like I understand whatever little story there is.-I only experienced a little nausea towards the beginning but that was quickly remedied by focusing my vision on the enemy while flying. Conclusion: The experience, while cool, is watered down by low resolution, complete disconnect from the story due to bad audio mixing of dialog, and the fact that this game is already a watered down VR experience of the PC version. 5/10

I was underwhelmed by the ham fisted story telling of this game and nonsensical virtue signaling of its DE&I directives. Especially in the DLC. I‚Äôm saying this as someone with CE for both games, a big ass thunder jaw, a fricken Lego set, physical sound tracks, and a big ol canvas painting of alloy in from the first game in his game room. Stop it. Either make these scenarios make sense and less like happy day dream fanfiction or move on. That isn‚Äôt even getting into alloy stopping more frequently than Yuna to defeat Syn when she is clearly in a rush. Don‚Äôt think gameplay is without criticism here either. For every improvement there was a step back. No gradual escalation to help get the player involved in crafting, some how this went from something you embrace at the start to almost an end game exclusive activity. The hunt seemed less relevant then in the first game. Which is weird since it is less involved. Don‚Äôt even get me started on enemy design and boss fights Point is decline in that Sony Quality that comes with a first party studio brand.

Author: cusman
Comment: It is a grand adventure that keeps getting better, but it doesn‚Äôt immediately suck you in. It does have way too much content but I think majority of that is optional. It also has potential for a ton of grind if you get into the gameplay systems and want to take on the toughest optional Abyss challenges with multiple viable squads, because the leveling system is exponential. Keep your world level down and ignore Abyss and you don‚Äôt have to worry about any grind and can enjoy the best most varied part of game which are the archon and character story quests and the exploration / discovery of each new area that gets added. The limited time events which happen every month can be a significant distraction from completing other content. I have 500+ hours in the game over the last ~3+ years now.

Author: ReptileHand
Comment: I, like many people, was un-impressed with the shameful Splatoon copy-cat like this game claims to be. Until I actually played it. WOW IT‚ÄôS SO FUN. If anyone else sees this and saw that they missed the Beta weekend, look for it again in the future! It‚Äôs insanely fun and addicting, just like Splatoon, but with it‚Äôs own twist. The graphics are bright, colorful and pop out with the resolution quality. Each person has their own abilities and ultimate that rarely do much so you‚Äôll have to rely on your own personal weapon shots. You foam the ground, causing you to build walls that you can climb for higher ground while moving around on a foam board for a quick exit or chase. Foaming the area isn‚Äôt mandatory too! Some characters and game modes need some more tuning. The MVP style battles are SUPER fun‚Ä¶ but the Elimination round style of battles finish quicker than the actual queue for them. I‚Äôm glad my friend told me to play, because I probably wouldn‚Äôt have. I hate to say this, but in a sea of service games, I would spend money on this in the future.

HOWEVER if you are interested in the TR soundtracks check out ‚ÄúThe Tomb Raider Suite‚Äù which is a project by Nathan.It features various tracks from TR I, II and III. It‚Äôs a live album played by the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra.EVEN BETTER YET if you prefer the original sound check out ‚ÄúThe Tomb Raider Suite Synth Mixes‚Äù which features the mixes from the live album but is instead written and played entirely by Nathan using the original equipment he used in ‚Äô96, 2 x Roland JV1080 synthesizers. It really sounds like a remastered version of the original soundtrack.

Comment: Thanks for these types of posts; I enjoy them, but a better way to celebrate Spyro would be to provide a PS5 enhancement patch for the Reignited Trilogy. Platformers benefit greatly from high frame rates. It would be nice to also see patches for the Crash N. Sane Trilogy and CTR Nitro-fueled in particular. We really appreciate the many enhancement patches developers have provided for PS5, but Activision has not offered even one, I believe. The same can be said about Take-2/Rockstar. It‚Äôs odd that the two most commercially successful publishers won‚Äôt offer this to their customers, but many indie devs and struggling publishers have done so for several of their titles (shout out to Ubisoft).

Author: xDD90x
Comment: @Heaven1134I said ‚Äúenhancement patches‚Äù, not native PS5 versions that customers must pay for, which is the case with GTA V. Many developers have offered free PS5 upgrades, but Activision and Rockstar aren‚Äôt one of them. PS5 patches are free updates to the PS4 games that allow them to run with enhancements on PS5 (usually 60fps). Some example games that received such patches are:God of WarHorizon Zero DawnDays GoneRatchet & Clank (2016)The Last of Us 2Assassin‚Äôs Creed Origins & OdysseyFar Cry 5Dying LightShadow of the Tomb Raider

Author: Door_to_Light_95
Comment: Spyro on the original PS1 was one of the first games I ever played. As such, the series is incredibly special to me. This article was a great read, and I enjoyed reading the remarks and comments of both the Insomniac and Toys for Bob staff. I also absolutely loved how Toys for Bob remastered the original three Spyro games. I‚Äôm so incredibly thankful that they put so much care and effort into making sure the remastered versions were so faithful to the originals. It was such a wonderful experience replaying through these games I experienced as a kid, and having just as much fun doing so. One thing I have always found special about Spyro (and one of its biggest advantages) is that you get to play as a dragon for crying out loud! Even to this day, there‚Äôs not many games where you play as a dragon. Spyro has always been special because of that. And of course, it‚Äôs fun and appealing gameplay, charming and entertaining characters, incredible music, and how well it manages to succeed in giving that collectathon vibe that 3D platformers are known for. Happy 25th anniversary, Spyro! (As a side note, I know Activision is getting closer and closer to being bought by Microsoft. I know the likes of Spyro and Crash Bandicoot aren‚Äôt as huge of games as Call of Duty, but I still hope that as Microsoft has said Call of Duty will remain multiplatform, that the likes of Spyro can as well. I‚Äôm okay with Microsoft owning Activision, and I honestly think my two childhood friends, Spyro and Crash Bandicoot, are in much safer hands being owned by Microsoft than just Activision in its current state. Activision has been having a lot of internal difficulties in recent years, and I think Spyro and Crash are in a safer home with Microsoft if the deal goes through. That being said, I sincerely hope that Spyro and Crash can still be multiplatform games ‚Äî especially if we get new Spyro and Crash games going forward. Having them at least available on PlayStation would be wonderful, considering the significant history that Spyro and Crash have with PlayStation. I‚Äôm totally all for Spyro and Crash being played by more people, across all platforms. I just hope that PlayStation gamers can still have access to potential new Spyro and Crash games in the future too. Regardless, though, happy 25th anniversary Spyro! I hope to see you star in a new game soon, and I am forever thankful for all the memories I cherish with you throughout the years!)

Author: Lithous
Comment: Seeing commercials and/or magazine ads of Spyro way back then got me interested in the series. Though I never got my hands on a game until Spyro 2: Season of Flame on the GBA. When I finally got a PS2, I eventually got a Spyro game to play on it, but it was ‚ÄúYear of the Dragon‚Äù rather than just ‚ÄúThe Dragon‚Äù. I never realized I started with the third game until Reignited showed a preview of the skateboard level, oops‚Ä¶ I never did play much of the original because I was lacking the PS1 memory card for it. The original trilogy is at least still available on the PS3, and I love all the work put into the Reignited trilogy as well! I am still hoping that there are chances we will see more Spyro remakes and/or new games in the future.

Author: TailstheFox3
Comment: The Spyro the Dragon Trilogy has been my favorite series of video games of all time, and the Reignited Trilogy was a refreshing way to enjoy them again. Many of the games that I have played since then have usually induced stress in one way or another (like turn-based strategy games toward the end with nigh hour-long final boss fights/army skirmishes, racing simulators with incredibly skilled opponents, etcetera). For me, there was never any stress or cause for concern with Spyro games (unless you were trying to get a platinum trophy with the Reignited Trilogy and defeat Ripto without getting hurt once). Each day, I could just relax, explore, and collect things. I don‚Äôt think that there could be a better gaming experience than that (although, I do realize that this is just my opinion). It was quite soothing. Everything about the games was phenomenal, but I was most impressed by the music. I found and downloaded the soundtrack for all of the games online 11 years ago or so, and I still listen to those songs to this day. Stewart Copeland did an amazing job composing the music for this series! I‚Äôve heard rumors that a new Spyro game might be in development, and I recall seeing a few Spyro Easter eggs in Crash Bandicoot 4. While I hope that a new Spyro game is in development, whether or not that is the case, I will also be a huge fan of Spyro for the games that he has already starred in. To everyone that had a hand in creating the Spyro Trilogy (and Reignited Trilogy), I thank you.

Author: ZanFear

Author: ZanFear

Author: mountain_spider
Comment: @ZanFear IT IS FOR REGULAR SURROUND SOUND SYSTEMS. If you mean people with stereo like 3-D audio in two channel stereo mode, that‚Äôs not regular surroundsound that‚Äôs a stereo system. Most likely, because their 3-D audio headphones, only has speaker position to simulate real surround sound in 2 channels with mini microphones helping to create a surround effect. VS bring it over to standard stereo speakers left, and right, you would only be getting echoes and simulations, but positioning and lack accuracy. This update allows 3-D audio to work out in a real surround sound system that has Atmos decoding.

Author: mountain_spider
Comment: @Zanfear If you mean regular surround with a Non Atmos/3d system, that‚Äôs like asking for DTSX but having an old Dolby receiver, it doesn‚Äôt have the built-in chip to decode it. Tempest 3-D basically is 3-D audio, all they had to do was repackage it so that the receiver can do it thing. The 2D ‚Äòstereo‚Äô, you‚Äôre talking about a simulated surroundsound it was done by echoes, and tricking the ear, but it wasn‚Äôt true surround which is why that effect works mostly better in headset, which is why they use it in their personal headphones. The stereo, classic kind was all simulated surround before surround came into effect. and that was not true surround. Because the effect wasn‚Äôt behind you clearly defined or diagonal or down from above.

Author: Hatchetforce
Comment: I can select Dolby Atmos without an issue but I do not see a choice to enable and Setup 3D Audio in the manner that currently exists for TV Speakers and Headphones. Is this not required to setup because it is auto processed by the Atmos setup through my Denon Amplifier?

Author: mountain_spider
Comment: It‚Äôs letting the receiver take over and process the information. Why would you want to set up and use your physical controller for TV 3-D audio when anybody that has Atmos or any 3-D system like DTSX already is fine tuned internally with a microphone for the room, which is more accurate than recording from a handheld controller. In other words, the system is just tossing the audio over to your receiver, if you did any room measurements with the microphone, you‚Äôre done and ready to go and it will automatically know how many extra speakers you have beyond 5.1 or 7.2 like if you have a 5.1 with Dolby 3-D speaker 5.1.2 etc. It‚Äôs far more accurate. The reason you had to do a test measurement with your controller to the TV speakers is because it‚Äôs only using two channel sound simulating three-dimensional audio from two speakers. However, now it‚Äôs just tossing the audio and whatever your system is already set up with uses it.

Author: Hatchetforce
Comment: I appreciate your answer but I just wanted official clarification that there was not a missing menu item. I know very well how room tuning functions with an AVR as I have had to do this multiple times and did so again recently with my latest Denon.

Author: Tolq
Comment: Nope, it isn‚Äôt required mate. 3D Setup is only required for simulated 3D audio. This new option basically repackages the 3D Audio information in an Atmos container for your AVR to sort out. The good news is that games with 3D Audio support will sound their best on a well configured Atmos capable system. The bad news is that upmixing via Dolby Upmixer, Auro3D or DTS:X is no longer possible because the sound from the PS5 is forced into an Atmos container, so the AVR thinks there‚Äôs nothing to upmix even if the stream only contains 5.1 audio in reality.

Author: Hatchetforce
Comment: I immediately noticed the difference when I jumped back into Baldur‚Äôs Gate. My Atmos speakers were singing. I have every PlayStation set of headphones to date, as well as some 3rd party ones, but I prefer my sound system. Home theater owners like myself have been waiting 3 years for this and so far the sound is remarkable. @Tolq, wouldn‚Äôt manually selecting Linear PCM or DTSX solve the upmixing issue?

Author: Tolq
Comment: @Hatchetforce, glad to hear you‚Äôre enjoying it as well ‚Äì I am keen to see how devs will tune their game‚Äôs audio in future to make better use of atmos capable hifi setups. Yes, if you know that a game doesn‚Äôt support 3D audio, you can change the audio settings on a system level to e.g. LPCM, and your AVR could then upmix it again. My point was that it is a bit clunky to do it manually on a game by game basis instead of the games themselves ‚Äútriggering‚Äù Atmos when applicable, but it is a minor downside all things considered.

Author: Moftwell
Comment: Very excited about the implementation of foveated rendering on PSVR2. That could be gamechanging; an absolutely massive deal. The scale offered by Hello Games supporting full-game VR for NMS has always been beyond reproach, but the visual sharpness (particularly in the mid-distance and beyond) has maybe just held it back from breaking through the top-tier of PSVR2 games. If HG have managed to crack that here‚Ä¶ I really need to try this update when I get home! And as always, the other updates are a mix of improvements, iterations and reimaginings that partly offer the playerbase cool things they were asking for and partly offers even cooler things they‚Äôd never thought about. Everyone knows the story of NMS by now, but Hello Games continue to build their exemplary reputation for post-launch support. Happy seventh birthday, Sean. Your team fully deserves the celebrations.

Comment: Wow! What an Update for PSVR 2! This is what we were all waiting for. As a beginner I stop playing it once I saw it had low-res, blurry for PSVR 2 and just decided to wait for this update and my goodness! I‚Äôm so glad I waited. Just gave No Man‚Äôs Sky 5 hours straight today lol.

Author: Moftwell
Comment: Quick explainer of how time works for MrXile: The state of a game at launch is a result of work done prior to launch. Improvements made to a game after launch is a result of work done after launch. This concept is pretty basic. Yep, we all know how the game was during that first year. But by that point the developers had begun working on the post-launch improvements. NMS launched seven years ago. Thus, it has been seven years of amazing work to reach the point the game‚Äôs at now, and it‚Äôs possible to hold both that opinion and the opinion that the game wasn‚Äôt good on release. Seems weird to consider ‚Äòthey made the game better now than it was at launch‚Äô as blinkered, but I get it; words can be difficult.

Author: Shin-Ra
Comment: If only Konami/SIE/Bluepoint could‚Äôve agreed to take Bluepoint‚Äôs existing work on MGS2 and MGS3 and upgrade it properly for PS5, not just 720p60 ports with control tweaks for the lack of analog buttons. They could‚Äôve reinstated Snake‚Äôs Nightmare (Guy Savage) and Snake vs Monkey in MGS3 to make a truly definitive edition with no missing content. PS1 content (MGS) doesn‚Äôt look great rendered at high resolutions but ‚Äòsmooth SD‚Äô is possible by rendering internally at a very high resolution, then downsampling (point sampling/nearest neighbour) to ~320√ó240 for a pixelly, yet smoothly anti-aliased picture. Original (circle/cross swapped) and modern controls options could be included. MGS‚Äô original dual analog controls weren‚Äôt very analog, that could be improved. If only an IP holder and developer that really cared was handling these remasters‚Ä¶ ports.

Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots was synonymous with PlayStation and for the longest time, Metal Gear Solid 2 was the only multi-platform game. Twin Snakes was exclusive to the GameCube and never did see PlayStation shores but, PlayStation is losing everything that once defined its console to Xbox, maybe SEGA wasn‚Äôt much to duke it out with but Xbox is a headache and everyone‚Äôs shifting, even when PlayStation has become more developer friendly and apologized for the ‚ÄúPS3 incident‚Äù if you want to call it that, it‚Äôs like previous relationships never mattered. I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on. Seemed like Street Fighter had gone PlayStation as well with V exclusive the whole generation, not timed and with Sony buying EVO you‚Äôd think Sony would be the place to play but, Street Fighter 6 launched day and date with Xbox Series X and what are PlayStation fans getting? Remake after remake of The Last of Us, and studios becoming distracted to make film. Is PlayStation getting ready to leave the industry and focus on film? It sounds ludicrous, right? But we‚Äôre seeing fewer games and Gran Turismo popping up, The Last of Us TV adaptation of the game, and Twisted Metal‚Ä¶.. Sony‚Äôs PlayStation Showcase showed a lot of games that Xbox were quick afterwards to say: ‚ÄúAnd a lot of that is also coming to Xbox, have a good day, see you at our Showcase‚Äù which was better than Sony‚Äôs they didn‚Äôt show any actual gameplay, which was a letdown, but they made their case for ‚ÄúThis is why you need Xbox‚Äù. What was Sony‚Äôs PlayStation Showcase? This is what to expect in gaming for the remainder of the year‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. What? Why didn‚Äôt you do a pre-show letting everyone know, this is third-party, and then rock everyone‚Äôs world and blow our teeth out the back of our heads with PlayStation content ‚ÄúThis is why you have to have a PlayStation.‚Äù No, instead their Showcase was free marketing for Xbox while Xbox said ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôll show you why Xbox is center and you don‚Äôt need a PlayStation because all of this, you can‚Äôt play it on PlayStation,‚Äù and no I‚Äôm not talking about the additional hour spent on Starfield. Author: Door_to_Light_95
Comment: I‚Äôm very happy that Gran Turismo 7 keeps getting such great support and so many new updates. Keep up the good work! I know that it‚Äôs probably not the highest priority, but I think it would still be beneficial to add a few more options to offline local multiplayer. The 2 player offline multiplayer is good as it stands now, but it would still be really nice to see some updates to the local multiplayer, even though it‚Äôs not as popular as online multiplayer. One suggestion would be to allow the screen for each player in splitscreen to hide the UI and allow the game itself to fill the entirety of each player‚Äôs screen. Having that UI with all the neat stats and indicators is a nice option, but I don‚Äôt think having it as the only option for 2 player offline races is all that great. I for one, would love to play a 2 player offline race with a friend on the couch without the busy UI surrounding each player‚Äôs side of the screen. It kind of makes the area of the screen with the actual race going on rather small and more difficult to see in my opinion. It would be nice to be able to have an option for each player‚Äôs side of the screen in splitscreen to fill the entirety of the screen too, for those of us who want to play local couch races without the UI taking up so much screen space. I know this probably isn‚Äôt the highest priority, but even though online multiplayer is so big nowadays, there‚Äôs still quite a lot of people like me who also enjoy local multiplayer with friends in person too. Having some additional options added to the 2 player offline multiplayer would still be a worthwhile addition in my opinion, even though online multiplayer is the much bigger focus.

Author: turniplord
Comment: Sounds good ‚Äì 2 questions and some suggestions‚Ä¶ Q1. will the silly 1,000 game limit be removed if we have an 8TB M.2 in the PS5? At the moment, you can‚Äôt install over 1,000 games on the external HDD (PS4 and PS5 backups), so I‚Äôm guessing the limit will also be in place on the internal drives. I have around 500 games installed on my internal 4TB M.2 but I won‚Äôt be upgrading if the limit is still there ‚Äì it‚Äôs the same silly pointless limit as the online saves for PS4 being limited to a thousand FILES. Q2. How do we apply for the BETA? I‚Äôve been chosen for the last 4 or 5 BETAs but I see no link this time ‚Äì will past people just get access to it? Suggestions:1. You NEED to enable the ability to check for updates and manage save files by pressing Options on games that are installed in the library. At the moment you have to basically cancel whatever you‚Äôre playing and start the game. Then, when it‚Äôs on the home screen, you can then do the above two operations ‚Äì this should be possible without starting the game. 2. The PS5 NEEDS to give you a warning if you‚Äôre starting a game but you have one already open. I‚Äôve accidentally closed games so many times, losing progress and even corrupting saves simply because the console doesn‚Äôt ask if you‚Äôre sure you want to close the game to continue (The PS4 did this, so why can‚Äôt the PS5) 3. You NEED to bring back the DLC menu. It‚Äôs there, but you‚Äôve hidden it ‚Äì it used to randomly appear as an advert, labelled ‚ÄúAdd ons‚Äù, but then you stopped it from appearing altogether. The DLC menu has the ability to sort and filter every single piece of DLC without having to check all your games one by one and hope there‚Äôs a new piece of DLC and you can find it on the store. This menu shows you all the latest DLCs in date-order, letting you sort by name, date, price, and filter by soundtrack, levels, in-game items, etc‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs literally there in the background, you just need to assign it a static place on one of the store pages ‚Äì maybe replace one of the many Free to Play tabs (as there is one on almost every page of the store, two on the first page!) You also have a serious issue with games not removing the ‚Äòcoming soon‚Äô flag once they go live, resulting in over 900 games on the store being incorrectly listed and hidden below over 8,000 other games. I‚Äôve talked to Shu about this and over 300 developers and publishers over the last three years ‚Äì this is a major issue and I‚Äôm willing to talk to your UI team and provide detailed instructions on where the issue lies and how to fix it :)

Author: CommandingTiger
Comment: Can we talk about the project Q?Like what even is that?It feels like a split Dualsense with a low end tablet found on Ali Ex-press. It looks very cheap.That thing CANNOT cost more than 150$, 170$ at max if it is just a controller. What are you thinking?We asked for a hybrid console like the Switch but from PlayStation and Thus is what I get?We would have taken a 6 to 7 inch screen, with huge front facing speakers. but you put top facing speakers? ONLY 3 Hours of Battery life?! That‚Äôs because the screen size eats the battery up. The hybrid device we want is basically like the Q-Lite, but you actually attach a powerful Ryzen APU that rivals the PS5 in terms of power, those chips exists. Then you can detach that portion from the Q-Lite and dock it making it a PS5 slim. The dock would have hdmi out, 3 usb 3.1, ethernet, an optical disc drive and a SSD expansion slot.(and aadditional cooling solution) combining both the Q-Lite and PS5 slim would essentially make it a hybrid console you can take on the go.Instead your doing half bad job and turning it into a Wee U only device. The fact it‚Äôs using Android as opposed to a dedicated OS gives me 0 hope for this device being a complete waste. If you‚Äôre not going to make a Switch like hybrid home/mobile console then you might as well cancel it before you‚Äôre forced to sell them for 50$ in a clearance. What we want is a Switch like handheld but with the power of the A s u s R O G Ally.We do NOT want the Logi-tec G-Cloud. The handheld PS5 can be either a home console or a portable device, when it is docked, it gets access to a bigger library of games from digital to physical as well as a performance boost, not draining the battery of the handheld portion, the Q-Lite. The Q-Lite hybrid would retain the touchscreen, unlike the switch that disposes of it when docked. So let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs plugged in the wall, the screen can act as it‚Äôs TV if no TV is available without draining the battery as much while boosting performance.You can charge 500$-600$ for all this portable hybrid console.Price is not a issue, Purpose is.  It all it is, is a controller, then 150$ is more than enough.

Author: KazeEternal
Comment: @tasso11000 you‚Äôve been reading too many Kotaku and Polygon articles. Anyone with half a brain can easily point out the flaws in that logic. 1) If the product doesn‚Äôt sell well enough to justify the port on the new platform it loses money or breaks even. Guess what has happened with more than a few of their releases like Sackboy. Go google it. 2) Hardware eventually does make a profit once it becomes cheap enough to manufacture. Sony is no stranger to hardware refactors and price drops. Eventually that does lose them money down the line. 3) Steam is almost like a 1st party at this point. Sony has to pay Valve for every release they put on their store front, essentially reducing the amount of money they make.  Unless we start seeing a PlayStation OS or PlayStation Launcher on Windows, don‚Äôt expect this to ever change. (believe me I‚Äôd love to see either of thsoe things). If memory serves valve‚Äôs cut is bigger than what sony asks of 3rd parties on  playstation. This idea that its ‚Äúgood‚Äù to release it every where to get the greatest number of eyeballs doesn‚Äôt really hold much water the minute you start examining the technical debt that happens from it. A lot of these studios leave their PC versions for development purposes in pretty abysmal states the closer they get to release. That isn‚Äôt even getting into the lack of feature sets they‚Äôll need to bolt on, testing across multiple configurations, learning how to make things tick on PC like they do on a console. This where things get bad. The success and support of your platform stems from its popularity. Imagine a certain sony license does make it big on PC, which do you think will get more attention in the future. We see it already with titles that sell better on playstation. Even Horizon is kind of broken compared to the console version.

Author: HollowKage
Comment: I absolutely loved this game, characters, story, game play, and gruesome deaths. Striking Distance Studios created a horror masterpiece. The atmosphere is eerie and untrusting a lot like when you have to make your way through frozen infected biophage pathogens in chapter 5, Lost. The enemies are unique and challenging from the lowly Grunts to the more complicated Security Units. No game is perfect though, for it being a survival horror it relies pretty heavy on the prison baton and the dodge, though both become second nature as you trudge through the infected prison. Their could‚Äôve been better weapon cosmetics and some weapons you need weren‚Äôt available while other weapons you didn‚Äôt need were. I was hoping to wear the suit with helmet more and every gamer should know you guys are the master mind behind the original Dead Space, that being said I expected the suit to work more like Issacs suit in DS, helmet effects anyways. I bought the season pass and I plan on getting Final Transmission soon, here‚Äôs hoping you guys are able to make a second installment and that you guys ultimately are able to make a franchise out of it.

Author: oppositesleeper
Comment: Impressions after playing the demo.Biggest pro ‚Äì graphicsBiggest con ‚Äì block/dodge mechanicThe game looks good and controls reasonably well. The animations are fairly smooth with some of the directional combat feeling a bit off when not locked on. The worst part is the blocking and dodging. The environment makes it really easy for enemies to corner you, there are tons of little obstructions that cant be broken and you can get stuck really easy because of the weak sidestep dodge. The game encourages blocking but it feels more based on luck than actual timing. First death was on the first boss in the circus. It took hours to beat him because i was focusing on trying to get the block down. You can make it to the first boss without blocking once but then you MUST master it in order to continue. Once i finally beat it i wasnt looking forward to continuing. It was far more frustrating than fun and didnt come with a sense of accomplishment at the end. I didnt even finish the demo.

Author: Iozefka
Comment: Demo Impressions: *Lore: There isn‚Äôt too much setup or exposition at first, but once you get to Kat Hotel you learn more of the world and it became a more interesting place to explore. It has many similarities in its narrative with Bloodborne; Ergo = Blood Healing,  Ashen Blood = Petrification disease(?). I just hope that it is different enough to establish its own identity. *Combat: Basic and Strong attacks felt good. My main concern so far is the Legion Arm Loadouts never were that useful and there didn‚Äôt seem to be additional attack animations right after dodging or running forward, so the encounters lacked some fluidity. Aside from leveling, the P-Organ (mechanical heart?) progression system may serve to add additional depth, but it is something you only get to try at the end of the demo. As you progress through the game I want to see more creativity for combos and weapons. *Graphics and Level Design: The look and feel of the world feels very polished. You can expect the classic Souls-like shortcuts, being ambushed on narrow alleys and resources hidden around every corner. 0

Author: Ethereal
Comment: Thanks for the demo! Really enjoyed what I played and you really nailed the souls feel and definitely feel the inspiration from Bloodborne. Only two comments would be: please please adjust the run/jog speed as P just seems to be moving so slowly and always seems to float. And the environmental details are a tad lacking. Some areas just seem a little barren. Keep up the great work!

Author: AdonisIsBeast
Comment: This game was literally SO CLOSE, to being a masterpiece based on the demo, but unfortunately they dropped the ball in a few KEY areas. They seriously should consider delaying for one year to fix this: Combat is extremely sluggish, hit boxes are not clear, and if fighting based on bloodborne mechanics (focus on dodging versus blocking), it is extremely frustrating and not fun due to how slow the character moves and how small the hit boxes are (also inaccurate). When dodging bosses and trying to attack afterward, movement is so slow that you cannot get rewarding hits into the enemy ‚Äì it is a slog. And if choosing to block in combat, the frames for when an enemy is open to a perfect block are not clear enough. The game should be difficult as it currently is, but the player should be able to properly study enemy moves a bit better.

Author: GunMetalManxx
Comment: Man, it sure takes you back. I loved demo discs and I played them all the time over and over again. There was a long stretch of time we didn‚Äôt see demos, they fell off the face of the earth suddenly and it seemed like a long time. Developers (gamers knew without question) were withholding demos of their games in fear you wouldn‚Äôt buy there game when you actually played it, they were worried about the quality and wanted to get ya before you could figure it out. There was this really stupid fiction going around that devs didn‚Äôt want to release demos because they got charged a dime every time someone downloaded the demo and it was too expensive when nobody was buying the game and ya just go: ‚ÄúThen develop and amazing game you, yourself, would want to play instead of cutting corners, actually make a good game.‚Äù So, I‚Äôm happy to see the return of demos, thank you! I got to relive my childhood Christmas one year when Capcom had a Resident Evil 2 demo, a Final Fantasy VII Remake demo, I believe, Medieval may have come out around that time, and I believe there was a demo for that and maybe Crash Bandicoot N‚Äôsane Trilogy and all that was missing was a Metal Gear Solid demo, and that would have been the major games from the PS1 era the year I got my PS1 for Christmas, so this is awesome to see, devs having faith and pride in the success of their work, that‚Äôs great!

Author: Skater_Ricky
Comment: I‚Äôm very excited to play Season 5 with all the new improvements such as the new map ‚ÄúReclaimed‚Äù and the rework of ‚ÄúHourglass‚Äù and all the coming improvements in Season 5 such as Squad Management, Squad Orders, Vehicle loud out rework, and supporting 2042 Attachments and Universal skins for Vault weapons but I have some serious questions that the Battlefield Community and my personal ‚ÄúPlatoon‚Äù would like to get answered. 1. Will there be a discounted or Free path to Elite Edition for those that bought the ‚ÄúBattlefield Ultimate Edition PS4 & PS5‚Äù bundle?‚Äì  Many players, including myself, pre-ordered Battlefield 2042 Ultimate Edition at full retail price via Pre Order.‚Äì I have personally pre-ordered Battlefield 2042 Ultimate Edition on June 9th 2021 (when the preorders first went live) and paid the full retail price of $119.99 USD.‚Äì I have played the game nearly every day since launch (November 18th 2021) on my PlayStation 5.As I‚Äôm writing this post there‚Äôs currently no upgrade path on the PS Store or In-Game to upgrade to Elite Edition from Ultimate Edition unless you pay at full retail at $99.99 USD. 2. Will you be bringing ‚ÄúPlatoon‚Äù Support to Battlefield 2042? (both In-game and via Battlelog stats)‚Äì Allowing for other Platoons to compete with each other in-game‚Äì Showing stats of the entire Platoon‚Äì Allowing Communication via Microphone and Text Chat in-game so an entire Platoon can work together as a unit. 3. Proximity voice chat‚Äì  Allowing players to communicate with other teammates in a close range such as calling for a revive, ammo, support such as repairs or calling out an enemy nearby. 4. Squad Management‚Äì Allowing the squad leader to remove/kick a player from the squad that is not contributing to the squad such as a player that‚Äôs AFK or never following squad orders (Sticking together as a squad) 5. More Maps‚Äì commitment in the future to adding more maps to the game 6. Year 2 support‚Äì  commitment in the future to support the game beyond season 5 for game improvements, weapon balances, vehicle balances, new weapons, new vehicles, new cosmetic skins for weapons and vehicles. Battlefield 2042 is just starting to get to a point where it needed to be at launch in regards to smooth gameplay, balances between Infantry and vehicles and all the little things in between but there‚Äôs still work to be done that the community would like to see improved and or added to the game as I mention above some of the big items that I and my Platoon would like to see added to the game. Look forward to seeing you on the Battlefield.Hoorah!

Comment: I really wish there was more to the Project Q handheld than simply remote playing PS5 games. I would be more than willing to invest if they managed to make it a handheld digital-only PS4 fine-tuned to stream PS5 games, especially considering the PS4 is already more than capable of remote playing PS5 games. I really don‚Äôt think the design helps its case: a large screen shoved into the middle of a controller doesn‚Äôt exactly seem ergonomic or portable. The biggest blow for me is the lack of an OLED screen, especially considering the Vita had it nearly 10 years prior. I suppose the price still remains to be seen, but with the licensed Backbone accessory costing $100 alone, I don‚Äôt see this being reasonably-priced enough for it to be a worthwhile proposition to most people; even if it works as seamlessly as a certain other console‚Äôs ‚Äúgamepad‚Äù accessory, it seems far too niche to really catch on. I‚Äôd love for Sony to continue pursuing handhelds, and I understand they want to allocate all their development to big-budget games on their core system, but this doesn‚Äôt seem like the right way to go about it.

Author: KazeEternal
Comment: Wifi exclusive Project Q? I got a wishlist for you: 1) Give USB-C hub support for wired Connections. I do this with my phone to get a much more stable connection to my PS5 when remote playing. WiFi in my house is ok and will be getting a Wifi6 overhaul eventually, but my 1gig network is better suited and works great with my PS4 and Phone when remote playing my PS5. 2) Make this sucker have a dock. Not just a charging dock, but a TV dock. I want to be able to dock this device to my TV and allow me to have a full PS5 like experience, using an actual dual sense. No need to go crazy with detachable groups that attach to a controller dock with a touch pad in the middle (though appreciated). If I‚Äôm playing in another room away from my PS5 and the TV suddenly becomes free in that room and I don‚Äôt want to go to the other room, it would be nice to just dock and play. I‚Äôd buy multiples of these docks for each room with a TV if this was a thing.  A lower cost charging dock without all the bells and whistled would be a nice accessory as well. 3) I‚Äôm already asking for Dual Sense support in number 2, so this should be a natural fit. Bluetooth support for multiple devices. Headsets, controllers, keyboards. etc I want it all. Look overall I‚Äôd rather have a PS Vita 2 with backward compatibility with digital PS4 games. If this thing is going to be what I think it is, we‚Äôre looking at a 200 dollar product which is going to make people ask ‚Äúwhy didn‚Äôt you just make a Vita 2?‚Äù I doubt it‚Äôll be 100 dollars like the backbone. My little wishlist here will certainly push that price up. So go the distance, don‚Äôt stop short like with the Vita (no tv out and stupid touch screen, zero innovation to adopt Dual Shock 3/4 layout) and PSP (lacking a second analog stick and again no TV out or Dual Shock support till PSP Go which was a dumb move to do to the PSP2000 and 3000).

Comment: The way I see it. This project Q gives you basic streaming functionality.Probably Spotify as well.Allows you to put on MP3 music and video as well.Hopefully PSP/PS Vita ‚ÄúTV‚Äù backwards compatibilityAlso comes with Cloud Streaming with PS5 server blade. Then it becomes an hybrid device where you attach to the USB C into and add the AMD Z1 EXTREME processor that plays PS4 and PS5 games, while PS5 games would run 1080p/60fps.*16Gb Ram GDDR6*AMD Z1 EXTREME Processor OR the PS5 SoC on a handheld There is a possibility of detachable controller into a full DS5 like the Hybrid Switch. The fact they are using 6 Nano meters processing makes it cooler for the PS5 to run and it‚Äôs fairly easy to get the power of a PS5. The Nintendo Switch found a large portion of the market.Having the same Ryzen architecture, having the same/similar powered would be significantly different than running games on an ARM processor directly and forcing development to build from the ground up an entire game, instead to adjust and optimized the existing games at a lower resolution and not ‚Äúexclusive games‚Äù made specifically for that hybrid handheld, it would be instead a hybrid PS5 home/portable console. It would also have it‚Äôs own dock for additional storage + HDMI to TV and Ethernet, Additional USB ‚Äì C and USB for PS VR2. They can still do all of that with a simple attachment at the back of this device and has USB -C connected to it, you can output video via USB-C. So from that Ryzen processor you‚Äôd be able to play PS5 or even PS4 games.

Author: CommandingTiger
Comment: The Asus ROG Ally that has similar Teraflops as a PS5 is retailing at 700$. I don‚Äôt see how they could be able to make a system as powerful as a PS5 on a mobile device and not charge the same if not more than a PS5. Which is probably why they have this Q Lite as a stand-alone device because you can put in different powered hardware attached to the back of this Q Lite device. So if you‚Äôre only willing to spend 400$, you‚Äôd get a portable device as powerful as a PS4 Pro (that‚Äôs with the Q-Lite), but won‚Äôt play PS5 games.  You want the bigger hardware, then you‚Äôre spending more on this device to get a full PS5 out of it. Then you‚Äôre probably looking at 600$ in total minimum. I totally agree with you that we need a new PSP type device,  Sony however will Not make any other games than their AAA for console nor compromise the experience. However, we‚Äôre not dealing with completely different architecture, it would be all Ryzen and basically run all the same games, except in a portable way. If you just want the Q-Lite, you‚Äôd basically stream games either via Remote Play or Cloud Streaming with PS5 server blades, these are coming down the line so that‚Äôs why they are waiting to show more on the device. Depending if they get the patents, they can make the dual sense controller detachable onto a middle portion holding the touchpad similar to Nintendo Switch. The good thing about the Q-Lite is that you can keep this device and just upgrade the hardware that runs games separately from the 9 inch OLED screen. So if a PS6 version comes up, then it would be cheaper than buying a whole new device. -Replaceable battery is a must.-Hall effect sensor analogs is a must, reduces cost by fixing stick drift.

Author: Yurinka

I‚Äôm not interested at all in competitive stuff, I prefer to play alone enjoying some good narrative and fun experience instead of frustrating competitive modes that require to spend too much time (which I don‚Äôt have) in a game to be fun. So if you aren‚Äôt including a single player campaign (even if it‚Äôs a short one like in CoD), please consider it for the future when possible as post launch content. Because even if I buy a lot of games and I was looking forward to this game because of the pedigree of the team and because I trust PS Studios, I never buy or play PvP only games. So if it‚Äôs PvP only, -specially if narrative free- I won‚Äôt buy it. In addition to this, I prefer game announcements where gameplay is shown, or minimum some tiny beats like in the Helldivers 2 announcement, or at least some in-game cinematics that show/explain a bit how the game looks, plays and feels. And Sony, I‚Äôm ok with some -not all- Sony games being released in PC 2 or 3 years (better if even later). But releasing all/most of them on PC, and specially releasing them day one on PC will dillute your brand and people will lose the need of buying your console, buying in your digital store, paying your game subs and buying your accesories.

Author: KazeEternal
Comment: ‚Äúplayer-driven stories‚Äù you lost me at this Ubisoft level of drivel. Usually a good sign a studio has lost touch with reality and what that means. ‚Äúplayer-driven stories‚Äù is born out of failure to make a polished product. The player is bored with your creation and ends up supplying their own entertainment instead of finding something else to play. It‚Äôs also sometimes built out of the failure of your product to be polished like most ubisoft titles. A case of the player laughing at you, not with you. Anyway that aside and being the only thing alienating me from buying this product. I‚Äôm glad bungie is focusing on a PvP game. After the mess of Destiny PvP which was honestly a feature the game didn‚Äôt need and could have been added much later, which felt like it was bolted on because of some expectation from Halo that it be there, I wouldn‚Äôt want to see that out of bungie again unless it was intentional. In all honesty PvP could have been awesome if given the time later that it needed. Seemed like a have a cake and eat it too situation that just blew up in bungies face when they realized they didn‚Äôt have the resources to balance a PvE space at the same time as PvP. That being said, I hope this sony acquisition doesn‚Äôt spell an end to single player experiences and larger PvE experiences from bungie. As annoyed as I am with Destiny, I think the original concept could be revisited with a new project and truly deliver on a sort of semi-MMO-RPG-SHOOTER many of us were hoping it could be.

If it‚Äôs a great game (which by the looks of it, it‚Äôs gonna be), most people would want to keep it to their collection anyway.‚Äì If it‚Äôs a collector‚Äôs / preference issue, I get it, I‚Äôm with you, but is it really a reason to miss the joy of playing this game in whatever form it‚Äôs available? On the one hand we complain when there‚Äôs a shortage of good games but on the other we won‚Äôt support a good game due to something like this. It doesn‚Äôt make sense to me. I for one, after so many years of waiting, wouldn‚Äôt want to miss the Alan Wake 2 experience for the world. Comment: People keep saying it‚Äôs just a Splatoon clone with a dense small minded outlook. It is very much a Splatoon Clone obviously. So what! That‚Äôs not a bad thing as Splatoon is fun as heck. Playstation doesn‚Äôt have access to anything like Splatoon since it‚Äôs a Nintendo 1st party IP exclusive. We get 3,000 shooters a year that are just like Doom, Halo, Call of Duty, or some zombie apocalypse game. Nobody complains about them being clones or what they are influenced by, they just play them and hopefully enjoy them. We get one Splatoon clone in the history of ever and everyone is outraged smh. Get over it! Keep that same energy the next time a Call of Duty clone or another zombie horde shooter is released. Also, Splatoon 3 has a lot of problems and room to improve. Like constant communication errors and disconnections because of P2P and not dedicated servers. No built in Team Voice chat, No easy invite system, Slowdown framerate issues especially in Salmon Run, lower resolution because of hardware limitations. And not being able to play ranked with your friends to name a few. FoamStars, could deliver a awesome expeirence to Playstation users because it will have the advantage of be powered by a PS5. Where we can at the very least have team voice chat built in and consistent framerates with smoother animations potentially. I love Splatoon and I have played it to a very high level and I will continue to play it. Nonetheless, I am open to this as well on my PS5. If it‚Äôs fun I will play it. If it‚Äôs bad o‚Äôwell it‚Äôs a opportunity missed by the developer. Either way there is enough room in the marketplace for another Splat-Like shooter. I just hope it has Gyro Aim (motion sensor aim) since its mimicking everything Splatoon so closely. Thats one of the most important and iconic features to me of the experience. PS4 and PS5 controllers both support motion aiming. So no excuses to not includeit as a option. I also hope it feels like a proper PS5 game. Not filled with obnoxious micro transactions for every little bit of the game. Or everything being pay walled behind nonsense currencies. I just hope Square Enix sets out to make a fun game. I‚Äôm interested.

I like the idea of the heists and a somewhat futuristic setting, but seeing no mention of a single player modes like at least a shortish narrative campaign leads to think it‚Äôs PvP only, which means I won‚Äôt play it. Also, the artstyle, character design and music seems too generic with too obvious references. I‚Äôd push a bit more in the sci-fi/futurish/cyberpunk part (but making it different from Watchdogs) and try to find more in this part a more unique and iconic art style while at the same time to try to differentiate it from other heist games like Payday or GTA Online. Remember that many of the classic and iconic Sony games/IPs since the PS1 days had a very unique visual art style, a very unique music style and at least one very unique gameplay. Remember Journey, Wipeout, Parappa, Loco Roco, Uncharted, Gran Turismo, Bloodborne, Gravity Rush, Team Ico, Horizon games and many more. Yes, they had their solid references. But also had unique visuals, music and gameplay that did help them stand out and become iconic and unique classics.

Author: vangiersbergen
Comment: My reasons why I won‚Äôt like it: ‚Äì a dumb ‚ÄòeAt ThE rIcH‚Äô narrative. This is so worn out and it‚Äôs tone deaf coming from a company that, just as much as billionaires, is trying to make money, and given that this will be a GaaS, it will do so in predatory ways. I would venture that there are many billionaires who have made their fortunes in much more honourable ways than GaaS with mtx. The Robin Hood comparison is particularly out of place because Robin Hood stole from the rich *to give to the poor*. He didn‚Äôt steal to make himself rich which seems to be the premise of this game‚Äì the game does a disappointing attempt to be ‚Äòhip‚Äô and ‚Äòcool‚Äô with Gen-Z characters and edgy haircuts etc. Not my style and given the amount of dislikes on the YT video, not anyone‚Äôs style‚Äì the cartoony, colourful aesthetic is extremely generic and done so many times in recent years. From Sony fans begging for Killzone/Resistance/SOCOM when it comes to GaaS it must have been clear Sony fans prefer a grounded/gritty experience rather than sci-if/cartoony and wannabe hip‚Äì Sony is attempting to force GaaS on its mostly single player loving fanbase. It would have probably been a better tactic to slowly ease them into it, ie give a popular Sony IP with a good single player a multiplayer mode in addition. This is how GTA Online became so popular because people bought GTA V for the single player and stayed for the multiplayer. TLOU2 Factions would have been perfect for this, but that got delayed and will probably get cancelled. I can give Sony a prediction: people who are into TLOU, Uncharted, GOW etc are not going to suddenly jump onto a colourful cartoony GaaS with a cringy anticapitalist narrative. What‚Äôs next, a ‚Äòfight the patriarchy‚Äô game?

Author: aquilla
Comment: (Repost ‚Äì What happened to the last one?! üòØüòê .) While I remembered quite a bit of the following and the PS Blog gives quite a detailed description of the differences between the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù R32 GT-R and the Nismo, reading Wikipedia and indeed from memory, technically its‚Äô description blurs the lines between ‚Äúnormal‚Äù 1990 Nismo and 1991 N1 Nismos, while there were further changes added to the N1 models with V spec I and V spec II versions coming out in 93 and 94, as well as separate non Nismo, V spec I and II‚Äôs which were produced in larger numbers than Nismo models‚Ä¶ While I saw several comments saying, ‚ÄúWow, another GTR!‚Äù, this is only the second R32 model to now exist in GT7, after the already included non Nismo, 1994 V spec II ‚Äì for comparison, completion and choice, as well as to match the older GT games, we need about ten more R32 Skylines in the game!! üòØüòÇü©≤üòÄü§òü§û Some of the following is noted in the description, all Nismo models include airflow and aerodynamic changes and improvements over standard GTRs, no rear wipers as well as no ABS brakes, as ABS isn‚Äôt allowed in Group A racing, while its‚Äô removal also saves weight‚Ä¶ As with normal GTRs, all Nismos include aluminium bonnets and front panels, which is possibly lighter than in normal GTRs . While the radio is removed as standard, it can be put back in optionally in normal Nismo models, while all Nismos are fitted with 16‚Ä≥ wheels and 225/55/R16 tyres as standard and feature cross drilled brake rotors ‚Äì they can be fitted with 17‚Ä≥ wheels as options, among other options, including sports exhausts and suspension braces. Quite interestingly, the replacement of the standard GTRs turbos for Nismo models was done in favour of reliability rather than performance and likely suffer from more turbo lag as they sacrifice spool up speed for their added reliability ü§îüòØüòÄü§ò . All normal Nismos were Gun Grey Metallic, while N1 models come in special thinner, lighter Crystal White paint ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs the N1 models that completely remove the radio, speakers, air conditioning and even the carpet from the boot!! N1 models also include a reinforced master brake cylinder and additional brake cooling ducts‚Ä¶ From 1993, the V spec I (or VICTORY Spec! üòÄü§ò), N1s added Brembo brakes, a retuned ATTESA E-TS system, and 17‚Ä≥ BBS wheels with 225/45/R17 tyres, as standard. The V spec II in 94 only increased the tyre and wheel width and size to 245/45/R17, with no other changes noted‚Ä¶ Possibly only the V spec II but likely the V spec I as well is noted as being 50kg heavier than a standard GTR and 80kg heavier than a standard Nismo, likely due to their larger and heavier wheels. There were various tuned special editions then, such as the 10 Zero R‚Äôs built by HKS with 591hp, which it‚Äôs believed only 4 remain in existence! üòØüòÄü§ò .

Author: AlaskanHandyman
Comment: I upgraded from a PS3 to a PS4 because a game I loved had a DLC that was only available on the PS4.   Historically developers have had to stop developing for older platforms because it becomes too difficult to support multiple versions of the same game when one generation of a console can do something that the other cannot, and performance suffers on the older console. I still have to have the PS4 disc in my system to play Forbidden West on My PS5.  Between the changes to the controller and the 4K 120Hz HDR the upgrade to a PS5 is worth it if you can also upgrade the displsy that you are using to play your games.

Author: treos100
Comment: ‚ÄúBring life back into the world: Gaia is the Spirit of Life, bestowed with the ability to bring beauty back into a world consumed by a dark void. Pressing L2 fires a boomerang-like orb of light, used to retrieve lost souls, attack enemies, and even make simple wires into green grindable rails. Holding L2 down instead charges her with light and upon release unleashes a blast of bright energy that replaces untraversable goop-covered land with safe grass and fauna to traverse.‚Äù WoOoOoO! yeah‚Ä¶SO unique‚Ä¶ -_- is this baby‚Äôs first platformer game or something? this sounds like it judging by this page and that screenshot at the top of the page‚Ä¶are you kidding me? ‚ÄúYou can pet the dog, cat, raccoon, horse, and more: After Us is a game with a message that we are responsible for the innocent animals of the planet. Not only is Gaia‚Äôs job to free the trapped spirits of the extinct critters of the planet, but she can comfort them with a pet using the DualSense controller‚Äôs touchpad once they‚Äôre saved.‚Äù i don‚Äôt care about that. i have always wondered where this fixation with HAVING to have animals you can pet in video games came from. there‚Äôs simply no point to it being in a video game. what does it add to the gameplay aside from just another button press to do X action? ‚ÄúThere will be tears: After Us presents players with a unique vision of a post-human Earth. You‚Äôll find statues of humans that once were, presenting a visual of their last moments. This feature is shared by some animals, some that passed away due to simple loneliness and sadness. Freeing these souls not only gives a bittersweet ending to a sad tale, but it also gives you a vision of their memories before the end of the world. Yet another turn on the emotional rollercoaster.‚Äù that‚Äôs your idea of a tear jerker game, dev? good grief! there‚Äôs‚Ä¶there‚Äôs no POINT to this game. tell me how it‚Äôs fun and engaging. tell me about the plot. the lore. the world itself. oh‚Ä¶but but you can pwess a button to pet ze animals‚Ä¶and and it‚Äôs it‚Äôs an open world pwatformer‚Ä¶and the EMOTIONS! and it‚Äôs a big‚Ä¶empty‚Ä¶post human‚Ä¶world‚Ä¶ there is no reason for me to buy this game. there‚Äôs no point to it.

Author: aquilla
Comment: The selection of cars in GT7 is ok, certainly better than Sport, but kind of terrible compared to older games in the series! In particular, it generally only has one version of various road cars, not always the best version available in real life and almost no newer refreshed or special edition models (and fewer older models, for that matter!) which is something the older games were very good at including! For example, I‚Äôm a big Mazda fan and while they have an impressive selection of racing and concept cars, the selection of road cars is very poor! On the 6, they only have the same (bloody diesel) 2015 model that was in GT Sport ‚Äì there‚Äôs no sign of any of the pretty significant model refreshs we got since and in particular no sign of the now three petrol engines it has since 2019* (or even the higher and lower power diesels available for the 6), nor any sign of the 100th and 20th anniversary edition models! While of the older models, the short run MPS is a must! (While some estate versions would be interesting to see and customise ü§îüòØüòÄü§ò.) On the fourth generation MX-5, they only have the 1.5L softtop, neither of the 2.0L engine, nor the hardtop or the 100th anniversary edition etc‚Ä¶ While the first gen MX-5 is present, it‚Äôs only the 89 version with no second, third generation or special edition models, such as the 30th anniversary edition. On the only recently added 3, it‚Äôs very strange that they only added the hatchback and not the saloon as well, while on older models, the 3 MPS would be nice to have as well‚Ä¶ üòØüòÄü§òü§û *The petrol engines available in Europe are 145hp and 165hp 2.0L engines and an unfortunately automatic only 2.5L 194hp version, which got a turbo in other markets! While as well as this 2.2L 174hp diesel, it was available with 150 and 184 hp as well. Anyway, I hope this changes soon! üòÄü§òü§û

Author: Hellooooo_Nurse-
Comment: That is really cool that this game has a retro look, but will still play and feel very modern and clean. I‚Äôm really interested in this game. While all of this is great. Above all, I‚Äôm hoping this game will have quality gyro aiming (motion sensor aiming) implementation for PS4/5 versions of Boltgun as a option. Not just limiting the gyro aim experience to the Nintendo Switch version only.  Or not implementing gyro aim at all. Which will definitely make the game DOA on the Switch for sure. Nonetheless, we PS5 owners want gyro aiming too, as our controller supports it as well. If this game doesn‚Äôt support gyro, unfortunately that is a huge deal breaker for me personally and many others that want this feature added. Hopefully, this game doesn‚Äôt let Quake (Remaster) out class it with quality good feeling gyro aim controls as a option. As Quake has usable functional gyro aiming natively on PS4/5. You know a legit retro shooter with modern control features as a option. Which is awesome! I‚Äôm hoping this game will follow suit and bring a great gyro aiming experience with the proper options in the settings to get it dialed in to the PS4/5 version of the game. Besides, gyro aiming not only enhances gameplay of shooters when implemented correctly. It does it Without the need of aim assist. It also doubles as a huge accessibility feature that makes FPS games possible for many people with various disabilities to be able to play. Not having this feature in the game is insensitive to the needs of those individuals. Hopefully, the devs at Auroch  Digital don‚Äôt screw this aspect up! We‚Äôll see when it‚Äôs released. Believing for the best!
